clusters.description: Baseline/reference distribution is underspecified or incoherent: the paper’s key probability claims depend on an unclear ‘no serious de dicto optimization’ baseline and an unspecified generative model of future social dynamics, so the conclusion may be an artifact of a pessimistic/ill-defined reference class.

Percentile/normalization anchor problem: defining ‘best feasible’ via a very high percentile (and then using ratios like 0.5/0.9) makes ‘mostly-great is rare’ highly sensitive to tail structure and to the chosen epistemic stance, potentially making the result tautological or scale-artifactual.

Multiplicative product-of-(independent)-factors model is unjustified: independence/near-zero assumptions, multiplicative aggregation, and factorization into many dimensions are doing the work; with correlations, latent variables, substitutability, thresholds, or different aggregators, the ‘needle-threading’ rarity claim can collapse.

Moral disagreement/pluralism doesn’t imply large value loss: the paper slides from ‘many views condemn something’ to ‘most value is lost / mostly-great is unlikely’ without a defended aggregation over moral views or a justified mapping from disagreement to big expected disvalue.

Institutional coupling / second-order governance makes many first-order hazards non-independent and less likely: the same high-quality institutions that yield ‘common-sense utopia’ (deliberation, rights, error-correction, corrigibility) would also prevent/correct many listed catastrophes, widening the target.

Single-flaw magnitude/fragility is overstated because errors may be moderate or correctable: the argument relies on flaws wiping out ‘most’ value and/or being irreversible lock-ins; but many mistakes could be revisable, compensable, or only partially value-reducing.

Population ethics/scale assumptions are doing heavy work: treating non-expansion or ‘wrong population size’ as a huge moral catastrophe presupposes contested totalist/scale-sensitive views; if many plausible views are person-affecting/average/thresholded, the ‘miss almost all value’ channel weakens.

Fat-tail/value-efficiency argument doesn’t establish a needle target: evidence for fat tails is weak or from the wrong reference class, and even if fat-tailed, there may be broad near-optimal plateaus or optimization makes high-value regions easy to find/replicate—so linear views needn’t be ‘fussy’.

Linearity/separability doesn’t imply a single blueprint or extreme specificity: even if value is separable/additive in resources, there can be many diverse parcel-level optima/near-optima; the paper’s move from separability to ‘must recreate one best arrangement’ is not shown.

‘Linear ⇒ must use (almost) all cosmic resources’ overstates scale necessity and ignores feasibility/risk/coordination constraints: expansion may be costly/risky or not part of the feasible optimum; benchmarking against ‘accessible universe’ can create a misleading cliff.

Taxonomy/framework mis-specification: the paper’s bounded/unbounded and linear/sublinear taxonomy (and related formal assumptions) misclassifies or undercounts major moral theories, potentially generating ‘fussiness’ as a modeling artifact.

VNM/cardinal-comparability restrictions bias toward fussiness: by filtering to complete VNM-style orderings and scalar value functions, the paper excludes robust/pluralist/incomparabilist/constraint-first views that could underwrite ‘easygoingness’, making the conclusion conditional on the chosen decision-theoretic framework.

Intertheoretic comparison/normalization under moral uncertainty is underdetermined: different normalization/anchoring choices flip recommendations; therefore moral uncertainty can’t robustly be used to support ‘fussiness’ or ‘no easy eutopia’ without a principled selection of comparison method.

Cosmology/aliens premise is a hidden hinge: arguments that bounded views are ‘effectively linear’ (hence fussy) depend on speculative assumptions about a vast universe full of alien value; if life is rare or our influence is large, the conclusion changes.

Separate-aggregation bounded ‘10^22’ hypersensitivity is a modeling artifact: the mapping from tiny bad fractions/resource shares to near-saturating disvalue is not defended; alternative disvalue geometries or scalable harm-prevention can make these views far less fussy.

Digital personhood creates adversarial/sybil-attack dynamics not addressed: once digital beings have rights/votes, actors can manufacture or spoof ‘moral patients’ to capture resources/power, turning compassion into an attack surface and making naive rights regimes unstable.
